_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Petroleum and Petroleum Products Merchant Wholesalers (except Bulk Stations and Terminals)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan (RMP)

Superior Gas Liquids - Propane Storage

Kendaia, Seneca County, New York



Executive Summary



1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Superior Gas Liquids (SGL) is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is an inherent part of SGL's comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with processes at our facilities.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent potential releases of regulated substances. SGL does not maintain any employees at the rail storage facility, as the only 'process' in the context of this Risk Management Plan is propane storage in rail tank cars on rail siding leased from Finger Lakes Railway (FGLK). As such, SGL depends upon and coordinates with FGLK, Seneca County Fire Department, and the Seneca County Office of Emergency Management to provide response and response expertise.



2.    Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The facility's primary activity is receiving, storage, and shipping propane as liquified petroleum gas (LPG) in railcars. Railcars are placed by FGLK on a rail siding, secured against unwanted movement and protected from collision with other cars/trains, stored for up to one (1) year, then picked up by FGLK for transport to Phelps Sungas, Geneva, NY. Each 33,000-gallon capacity railcar contains up to 135,771 pounds of propane. Up to 80 rail cars may be stored on site; therefore, the maximum amount of propane stored at the facility is 10,861,680 pounds.



3.    Worst Case Release and Alternative Release Scenarios 

RMP*Comp was utilized to evaluate worst case and alternate case scenarios for the required off-site consequence analysis for the facility. Scenario details are included in Section 4 of this Plan and summarized below. Several factors protect tank car(s) from damage (e.g.,

from collision, vandalism, or attack) and subsequent uncontrolled release of propane. These DOT 112 tank cars are constructed from 0.6-inch fusion welded high tensile steel, jacketed for thermal protection, and have an outer steel skin. Testing performed by the Federal Railroad Administration (RR 14-30, August 2014) indicate they can withstand 2.1 million foot-pounds of impact energy from a one (1) ft2 ram. Tank cars will be protected from unintentional movement and collision by set handbrakes on parked cars and locked derailers at the ends of each siding track. All valves and fittings are located under a locked, protective steel housing on the top center of the tank. A pressure relief valve prevents overpressuring, and a safety check valve limits the flow rate from the loading/unloading valve. Reasonable release scenarios are limited to a malfunctioning valve(s) or fitting(s), or intentional release by partially opening the loading/unloading valve such that flow would not activate the safety check valve.



A worst-case release scenario involves the release of the entire contents of all tank cars stored at the facility (10,861,680 pounds) and ignition of the resulting vapor cloud. Administrative controls or mitigation that would affect the release rate were not included in this scenario. At Stability Class F atmospheric stability, 1.5 m/s wind speed, and air temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit (25 degrees Celsius), the maximum distance to an endpoint of one (1) pounds per square inch (psi) overpressure (endpoint fixed by regulation) is 1.8 miles (Figure 1). A census search of population within a 1.8-mile radius using CensusViewer reports 1,754 persons.



An alternative release scenario involves the release of the entire contents of one (1) tank car. In the alternative scenario, 135,771 pounds of propane is released and the resulting vapor cloud ignited. The release is assumed to be undetected while ongoing and at a rate that does not trigger the flow-limiting ch

eck valve; therefore, active mitigation is not considered. At Stability Class F atmospheric stability, 1.5 m/s wind speed, and air temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit (25 degrees Celsius), the maximum distance to an endpoint of the lower flammability limit for propane (2.1% by volume) is 0.3 miles (Figure 2). A census search using CensusViewer indicates zero (0) persons residing within a 0.3-mile radius of the facility.



4.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

SGL will take all steps necessary to comply with the EPA's accidental release prevention requirements as set forth in 40 CFR part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place for the facility.



Process Safety Information

SGL will maintain a record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with all processes (see Appendix A - SDS, DOT 112 Rail Car Spec).



Process Hazard Analysis

A hazard analysis was completed as part of this Plan. Major hazards identified include fire and explosion. Process controls include the following:

?    Railcar construction that is resistant to puncture and heat;

?    Locked protective housings over all valves and fittings to discourage unauthorized access;

?    Pressure relief valves to prevent tank over-pressuring; and,

?    Safety check valves to limit flow rate and prevent uncontrolled release of tank contents to atmosphere.

 

Operating Procedures

SGL will maintain written operating procedures to ensure that activities within the covered processes are conducted safely.  These procedures will address various modes of operation. The information will be regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes (see Appendix B - Operating Procedures).



Training

SGL depends on FGLK to safely deliver tank cars into storage, secure them against unwanted movement, protect them from collisions, and remove them

from storage. FGLK has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that their employees involved in these processes are trained to an adequate level of competency.



Mechanical Integrity

SGL relies on the tank car supplier, which is the manufacturer and owner of the rail cars leased by SGL, to conduct maintenance and testing that assures mechanical integrity of its tank cars. SGL requires that any cars leased from the tank car supplier are maintained in accordance with applicable regulatory and industry standards (e.g., 49 CFR Part 180 Subpart F - Qualification and Maintenance of Tank Cars, and Association of American Railroads Manual of Standards and Recommended Practices, Section C-III, Specifications for Tank Cars). The tank car supplier maintains detailed maintenance records.



The tank car supplier performs inspections at a frequency of at least every 10 years. Where manufacturers of valves and fittings recommend a shorter inspection interval, the tank car supplier follows the manufacturers recommendation. Inspections and testing include bubble leak tests, ultrasonic testing of weld seams, thickness gaging, heat testing, and bench testing of valves prior to installation and at the manufacturer-recommended frequency.



SGL also performs, or causes to be performed, inspections to ensure tank cars have been delivered secure and leak-free. Visual inspections are performed to confirm cable seals and/or padlocks are present and intact on the protective housing covering valves and fittings. A gas detector is used to confirm the absence of leakage from valves and fittings. Security and leak inspections are typically performed within seven (14) days of railcar delivery (see Appendix C - Maintenance).



Management of Change

No process changes are reasonably anticipated.



Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-startup review is limited to ensuring the rail siding is in serviceable condition. FGLK is responsible for maintaining its track and associated infrastructure in

accordance with its rail maintenance program. 



Compliance Audits

If SGL operates the facility for more than one (1) year, it will ensure compliance reviews are completed at least every three (3) years as required by 40 CFR 68.58.



Employee Participation

SGL understands that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. SGL encourages its employees to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. Although SGL will not have any employees directly involved in the processes covered under this Plan, SGL expects its partners, FGLK and the tank car supplier, to similarly foster a proactive safety culture within their organizations. In addition, SGL will ensure that FGLK and its employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP, particularly information resulting from process hazard analyses.



Incident Investigation

SGL will conduct incident investigations as required by 40 CFR 68.60 for incidents that result in a catastrophic release or that could have resulted in a catastrophic release.



5.    Five-year Accident History

Does not apply at this time.



6.    Emergency Response Plan

Emergency shutdown procedures and operations are described in Appendix B - Operating Procedures. SGL coordinates its emergency response efforts with FGLK, the Seneca County Fire Department, and the Seneca County Office of Emergency Management. In the event of an emergency, responders will be notified via the Seneca County 9-1-1 system. Contact information for each response organization is stated in the Appendix B.



7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Does not apply at this time.

 

APPENDIX A

SDS, TrinityRail DOT112A340_W Rail Car Specifications

(see attached)

 

APPENDIX B

Operating Procedures

 

Operating Procedures (40 CFR 68.52)



Written operating procedures are required that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activi

ties associated with each covered process. Activities associated with processes covered under this Plan include delivery of railcars, storage of railcars, and removal of railcars.

?    Initial startup. Initial startup consists of delivery of railcars to a leased rail siding. This activity is the responsibility of FGLK, and procedures for safe movement and delivery of railcars are described in FGLK's operating manuals. Tank cars will be placed on the siding in a coupled state. The railcars will be secured against unwanted movement in accordance with FGLK's air brake and train handling rules. At a minimum, hand brakes will be set and each siding track will be equipped with a locked derailer on each end. Keys for derailer locks are kept by the FGLK Trainmaster. Other measures to prevent unwanted railcar movement (e.g., rail clamping wheel blocks, chocks, car stops, bump posts) may be used, as needed. When not open to receive tank cars into storage, rail switches will be locked to prevent unwanted movement of cars or trains onto the siding.

?    Normal operations. Normal operation consists of railcar storage on a leased rail siding. Tank cars will be inspected periodically to ensure that the protective housing over the valves and fittings is secured with a cable seal and/or padlock(s), and that valves/fittings are not leaking. Tank cars will be initially inspected within seven (14) days of delivery. Any leaks, evidence of tampering, or other safety or security concerns noted during inspection will be immediately communicated to SGL.

?    Temporary operations. This is not applicable.

?    Emergency shutdown and operations. In the event of an emergency, local emergency services will be notified via the Seneca County, Montana 9-1-1 system. Additional notifications will be made to FGLK's 24-hr emergency number. Only if it is safe to do so, steps will be taken to minimize the threat (e.g., closing open valves). Otherwise, the facility will be evacuated, and personnel will await inst

ructions from emergency responders.



 

Emergency contact numbers are stated below:



Emergency Contacts    Emergency Number    Non-Emergency Number

Seneca Co. Sheriff's Office    9-1-1    (315) 220-3401

Seneca Co. Emergency Management    9-1-1    (315) 539-1751

Seneca County Fire Department    9-1-1    

Finger Lakes Railway Emergency Nos.    (315) 781-0454    (315) 374-1573

Superior Gas Liquids - Director Logistics, HSE and Facilities    (403) 831-2550    (403) 831-2550

Superior Gas Liquids - Team Lead Logistics    (403) 837-5861    (403) 837-5861



?    Normal shutdown operations. Normal shutdown consists of removal of railcars from the leased siding. This activity is the responsibility of FGLK. Tank cars will be connected to a locomotive and removed.

?    Startup following shutdown or major change requiring hazard review. Startup following normal shutdown is not applicable. No major changes that would require hazard review are reasonably anticipated. Startup following emergency shutdown will only be undertaken following a root cause analysis and correction of the underlying cause(s) of the emergency. The Operating Procedures section of this Plan will be revised to incorporate learnings from the root cause analysis. After completion of the forgoing, startup can be undertaken in accordance with Initial Startup procedures in this Plan.

?    Consequences of deviations and steps required to correct or avoid deviations.  Deviations from these procedures could result in release of tank car contents, which in turn could have serious consequences up to and including fire and explosion. The facility's Safety and Security Plan describes measures intended to minimize risk associated with willful interference with or sabotage of operations. FGLK's standard procedures for railroad operations ensure that personnel are properly trained and multiple safety barriers are emplaced to protect tank cars from physical damage.

?    Equipment inspections. Tank cars will be inspected for security and leaks within seven (14

for maintaining its railcars, including inspections and testing in accordance with 49 CFR Part 180 Subpart F - Qualification and Maintenance of Tank Cars and industry standards, and practices per the Association of American Railroads Manual of Standards and Recommended Practices, Section C-III, Specifications for Tank Cars. The tank car supplier will perform inspections at a frequency of at least every 10 years. Where manufacturers of valves and fittings recommend a shorter inspection interval, the tank car supplier will follow the manufacturers' recommendations. Inspections and testing include bubble leak tests, ultrasonic testing of weld seams, thickness gaging, heat testing, and bench testing of valves prior to installation and at the manufacturer-recommended frequency.



SGL will perform inspections to ensure tank cars have been delivered secure and leak-free. A visual inspection will be performed to confirm cable seals and/or padlocks are present and intact on the protective housing covering valves and fittings. A gas detector will be used to confirm no leakage from valves and fittings. Security and leak Inspections will be performed within seven (14) days of railcar delivery.
